a.g: By those [angels] who extract with violence
And [by] those who remove with ease
And [by] those who glide [as if] swimming
And those who race each other in a race
And those who arrange [each] matter,
On the Day the blast [of the Horn] will convulse [creation],
There will follow it the subsequent [one].
Hearts, that Day, will tremble,
Their eyes humbled.
They are [presently] saying, "Will we indeed be returned to [our] former state [of life]?
Even if we should be decayed bones?
They say, "That, then, would be a losing return."
Indeed, it will be but one shout,
And suddenly they will be [alert] upon the earth's surface.
Has there reached you the story of Moses? -
When his Lord called to him in the sacred valley of Tuwa,
"Go to Pharaoh. Indeed, he has transgressed.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Etiquette of Quran Recitation
And sometimes one may have a correct purpose and seeks evidence for it from the Quran, and he deduces from what he knows is not intended by it, like one who calls to seeking forgiveness (Istighfar) during the pre-dawn hours (Al-Ashar) and deduces from His saying: 'Take the pre-dawn meal (Sahur) for indeed in the pre-dawn meal there is blessing,' and he claims that what is intended by it is taking the pre-dawn meal with remembrance (Dhikr), while he knows that what is intended by it is eating. And like one who calls to struggling (Mujahada) against the hard heart (Qalb), so he says: Allah the Exalted said: 'Go to Pharaoh, indeed he has transgressed,' and he points to his heart and indicates that it is what is intended by Pharaoh. And this type may be used by some preachers for sound purposes, beautifying the speech and encouraging the listener, and it is prohibited. And it may be used by the Batiniyya (esotericists) for corrupt purposes to deceive people and invite them to their false doctrine, so they interpret the Quran according to their opinion and doctrine regarding matters they know with certainty are not intended by it. So these arts are one of the two aspects of prohibiting interpretation by opinion (Tafsir bi al-Ra'y), and what is meant by opinion is the corrupt opinion that conforms to desire (Hawa) without sound independent reasoning (Ijtihad). And opinion encompasses both sound and corrupt, and what conforms to desire may be specifically named as opinion.

But Pharaoh denied and disobeyed.
Then he turned his back, striving.

And said, "I am your most exalted lord."

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Meditation
So do not think that an atom of the kingdom of the heavens is devoid of wisdom and judgment; rather, it is more perfect in structure, more precise in creation, and more comprehensive of wonders than the human body. Indeed, there is no proportion between all that is on earth and the wonders of the heavens. And for that reason, the Exalted said: 'Are you more difficult to create or the heaven? He constructed it. He raised its ceiling and proportioned it. And He darkened its night and extracted its brightness.' So return now to the sperm-drop and contemplate its state first and what it became second, and contemplate that if the jinn and mankind gathered to create for the sperm-drop hearing or sight or intellect or power or knowledge or spirit (Ruh), or to create in it bone or vein or nerve or skin or hair, would they be capable of that? Rather, if they wanted to know the reality of its essence and the manner of its creation after Allah the Exalted created that, they would be incapable of it.

So what is the proportion of all the seas and the earth to the sky, and they are changeable in proximity, while the heavens are firm, strong, preserved from change until the Book reaches its term? Therefore, He called it preserved, saying: 'And We made the sky a preserved roof' (21:32). And He, glorified be He, said: 'And We built above you seven strong ones' (78:12). And He said: 'Are you more difficult to create or the sky? He built it, raised its height, and perfected it' (79:27-28). So look at the Dominion (al-MalakÅ«t) to see the wonders of Might (al-Ê¿Izz) and Power (al-JabarÅ«t). And do not think that the meaning of looking at the Dominion (al-MalakÅ«t) is by extending your sight to it so that you see the blueness of the sky, the light of the stars, and their dispersion, for the beasts share with you in this looking. If this were the intended meaning, then why did Allah, exalted be He, praise Abraham by saying: 'And thus did We show Abraham the Dominion (al-MalakÅ«t) of the heavens and the earth' (6:75)? No, rather everything that is perceived by the sense of sight, the Quran expresses it with Kingdom (al-Mulk) and Witnessed (al-ShahÄdah), and what is hidden from the eyes, it expresses it with the Unseen (al-Ghayb) and the Dominion (al-MalakÅ«t). And Allah, exalted be He, is Knower of the Unseen (al-Ghayb) and the Witnessed (al-ShahÄdah), and Sovereign of the Kingdom (al-Mulk) and the Dominion (al-MalakÅ«t). And no one encompasses anything of His knowledge except by what He wills, and He is Knower of the Unseen (al-Ghayb), so He does not reveal His Unseen (al-Ghayb) to anyone except a messenger He has chosen. So, O intelligent one, reflect on the Dominion (al-MalakÅ«t), perhaps the doors of the sky will be opened for you, and you will roam with your Heart (al-Qalb) in its regions until your Heart (al-Qalb) stands before the Throne of the Merciful. And He darkened its night and extracted its brightness.
And after that He spread the earth.
He extracted from it its water and its pasture,
And the mountains He set firmly
As provision for you and your grazing livestock.
But when there comes the greatest Overwhelming Calamity -
The Day when man will remember that for which he strove,
And Hellfire will be exposed for [all] those who see -
So as for he who transgressed

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Remembrance of Death and the Afterlife
To the extent that you turn away from the worldly life (Dunya) and turn towards the Hereafter (Akhirah), you have followed his path which he followed. To the extent that you followed his path, you have followed him. To the extent that you followed him, you have become from his nation (Ummah). To the extent that you turn towards the worldly life (Dunya), you have deviated from his path and desired to not follow him, and you have joined those about whom Allah the Exalted said: 'So as for he who transgressed (Tughyan) and preferred the worldly life (Hayat al-Dunya), then indeed, Hellfire (Jahannam) will be [his] refuge.' So if you emerge from the abode of delusion (Gharur) and are just to your soul (Nafs), O manâ€”and all of us are that manâ€”you would know that from when you become [awake] in the morning until when you become [asleep] in the evening, you strive only for the immediate gains (Huzuz al-'Ajilah) and you do not move nor settle except for the immediate of the worldly life (Dunya). Then you hope that tomorrow you will be from his nation (Ummah) and his followers, and how distant is your assumption and how cold is your hope! 'Then will We treat the Muslims like the criminals? What is [wrong] with you? How do you judge?' And let us return to what we were in and concerning it, for the reins of speech have extended to other than its intended purpose, and let us mention now from the dreams (Manamat) that reveal the states of the dead what greatly benefits from it, since prophethood (Nubuwwah) has gone and the glad tidings (Mubashshirat) remain, and that is nothing but the dreams (Manamat).

Then He reduced all to one in another place, saying: "And he who fears the standing before his Lord and forbids the Soul (Nafs) from the desire (Hawa), then Paradise is the abode." For desire (Hawa) is a term that gathers all the inclinations of the Soul (Nafs) in this world, so asceticism (Zuhd) should be in it. And if you understand the way of summarization and detail, you know that some of these do not contradict others but rather differ in explanation and summarization. The result is that asceticism (Zuhd) is an expression for aversion from all the inclinations of the Soul (Nafs), and whenever one is averse from the inclinations of the Soul (Nafs), he is averse from remaining in this world, so his hope inevitably shortens, because he only wants to remain to enjoy and wants permanent enjoyment with the will to remain; for whoever wants something wants its permanence, and there is no meaning to the love of life except the love of the permanence of what exists or is possible in this life, so if he is averse from it, he does not want it. Therefore, when fighting was prescribed for them, "They said: Our Lord, why have You prescribed fighting for us? If only You had postponed it for us for a short term." So Allah said: "Say: The enjoyment of this world is little," meaning you do not want to remain except for the enjoyment of this world, so at that time the ascetics (Zahidun) became apparent and the condition of the hypocrites was revealed. As for the ascetics (Zahidun) who love Allah, they fought in the path of Allah as if they were a solid structure and awaited one of the two good things, and when they were called to fight, they would inhale the fragrance of Paradise and hasten to it like the thirsty hasten to cold water, eager for the victory of the religion of Allah or attaining the rank of martyrdom, and whoever of them died on his bed
